projects.description: Free software for enabling online anonymity. Tor directs Internet traffic through a free, worldwide, volunteer network consisting of more than four thousand relays to conceal a user's location or usage from anyone conducting network surveillance or traffic analysis. Using Tor makes it more difficult to trace Internet activity, including "visits to Web sites, online posts, instant messages, and other communication forms", back to the user and is intended to protect the personal privacy of users, as well as their freedom and ability to conduct confidential business by keeping their internet activities from being monitored.
projects.name: Tor

projects.description: Protocol for realtime decentralized communication and personal data storage.
projects.notes:
Tent mentions that it's still in alpha:
*"Remember, Tent is still in alpha, so itâ€™s not safe to use with information you would not want to be public and should not be considered reliable."*
projects.name: Tent

projects.description: A convenience and ease-of-use layer for use on top of dm-crypt.
projects.notes:
Gentoo maintains [a guide](https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/DM-Crypt_LUKS) for dm-crypt with LUKS.

Arch Linux also maintains [a guide](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Dm-crypt_with_LUKS) to dm-crypt with LUKS.

dm-crypt is available for DragonFly BSD.
projects.name: cryptsetup

projects.description: File based encryption tool with support for GNU/Linux, OS X and Windows.
projects.notes: EncFS is available for Windows through the "encfs4win" port.
projects.name: encfs

projects.description: Real-time disk and partition encryption software for multiple platforms.
projects.notes: While TrueCrypt is open source, it is developed in a closed fashion and may receive less review than a comparably openly developed project. That said, it is still probably the best option for file encryption on Windows and OS X.
projects.name: TrueCrypt

Also, you can export all your data at any time.

projects.name: Bitcoin

projects.description: Peer-to-peer cryptocurrency and open source software project released under the MIT/X11 license. Inspired by and technically nearly identical to Bitcoin (BTC), Litecoin creation and transfer is based on an open source protocol and is not managed by any central authority. Litecoin is intended by its developers to improve upon Bitcoin and offers three key differences.
projects.notes: Please note that new, digital currencies may be very volatile. Complete loss of your investment is possible for a number of reasons (software errors or attacks, identity theft, etc.). Be prepared!

projects.description: Multi-platform email application with mail encryption through the Enigmail add-on.
projects.notes:
Thunderbird does not encrypt your email by default. [Here is a guide](https://securityinabox.org/en/thunderbird_main) by Security In A Box to encrypting your email with Mozilla Thunderbird, GNU Privacy Guard (GPG), and Enigmail.

Thunderbird can optionally connect over Tor with the TorBirdy addon.

While Thunderbird can be used as a chat and IRC client, it does not offer encrypted messaging.
projects.name: Mozilla Thunderbird

projects.description: Install and enable this plugin in Pidgin for encrypted chat.
projects.name: Off-the-Record Messaging

projects.description: Free universal instant messaging client.
projects.notes:
Pidgin stores your IM account passwords in [plain text](https://developer.pidgin.im/wiki/PlainTextPasswords). You can avoid this by (1) not saving your password in Pidgin, (2) encrypting your file system with software like [TrueCrypt](http://www.truecrypt.org/), or (3) storing your Pidgin password securely with the Debian package [pidgin-gnome-keyring](https://code.google.com/p/pidgin-gnome-keyring/).

Pidgin with OTR and dbus enabled has a local security bug. See the [upstream bug report](https://developer.pidgin.im/ticket/14830) for more information and possible workarounds.
projects.name: Pidgin

projects.description: Multi-platform IM client for power users with built-in OTR support.

projects.description: Unix-like operating system descended from Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD), a Unix derivative developed at the University of California, Berkeley. The NetBSD project is primarily focused on high-quality design, stability and performance of the system.
